alert.note: Alert for Garfield; Wayne (Utah) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 11 at 3:42PM MDT until August 11 at 5:30PM MDT by NWS Saltlake
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 530 PM MDT THIS AFTERNOON FOR NORTHEASTERN GARFIELD AND SOUTHWESTERN WAYNE COUNTIES... At 342 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the headwaters of Sulphur Creek, Pleasant Creek, Capitol Gorge, and Grand Wash. Between 0.8 and 1.25 inches of rain have fallen in these drainages. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.10 to 0.30 inches are possible in these drainages. Flash flooding is ongoing in Sulphur Creek and adjacent drainages, and expected to begin shortly in Capitol Gorge, Grand Wash, and Pleasant Creek. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, slot canyons, and normally dry washes. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Capitol Reef National Park, Torrey, Fruita and Caineville. Park rangers report a flood wave near 1 foot in depth was observed on Sulphur Creek at 3:20 PM MDT and a larger flood wave up to 4 feet was observed in adjacent smaller drainages at 3:10 PM. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Remain alert for flooding even in locations not receiving rain. Dry washes, streams, and rivers can become raging killer currents in a matter of minutes, even from distant rainfall. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
